channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Secretary General Expresses Optimism About Climate Meeting
item.description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Thursday that he was optimistic that progress on curbing greenhouse gas emissions would be made at a conference in Lima, Peru.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Philippines: Travelers Stranded by Precautions for Typhoon
item.description: Ports were shut across the Philippines, leaving thousands of travelers stranded, and some local governments ordered evacuations on Friday as Typhoon Hagupit swept toward the country’s east.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Discord Persists About Woman Said to Be a Wife of ISIS Chief
item.description: Lebanese officials say they have detained a wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of Islamic State, but Iraqi officials say she was never married to him.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Meeting Afghan Leaders, Donors Pledge Support
item.description: The promises came during an international conference at which American and British leaders praised Afghan President Ashraf Ghani’s unity government.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, right, Afghanistan’s chief executive, with Secretary of State John Kerry at a conference in London.

item.title: Liberia Bans Election Rallies to Fight Ebola
item.description: In issuing the crowd-control order, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf argued that large concentrations of people at election rallies were precisely the situations that could spawn new infections.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIR MacDOUGALL and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia in Monrovia in October. She has banned mass gatherings linked to Senate elections.

item.title: Putin, Amid Stark Challenges, Says Russia’s Destiny Is in Hand
item.description: Russia’s president faces renewed unrest in Chechnya and a flailing economy amid continuing tensions with the West.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A battle between Islamist militants and government forces in Chechnya on Thursday left 20 people dead and a building in ruins.

item.title: Chris Christie Stumps for Energy, if Not for 2016, in Canada
item.description: On a trip to Canada, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey voiced his support for the Keystone XL Pipeline, and began fashioning what may be a foreign policy platform for a 2016 presidential run.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL BARBARO
item.media:credit: Larry Macdougal/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey met with Jim Prentice, the premier of Alberta, and energy company executives in Canada.

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Security Improving, French General Says
item.description: Gen. Éric Bellot des Minières, the commander of France’s military operation in the Central African Republic, says that security has improved considerably there and that the French authorities are studying plans for reducing troops.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Factory Attack Is Repelled
item.description: Nigerian police officers and soldiers repelled an attack on Thursday by gunmen on a French-owned cement factory in northeast Nigeria, where security forces are battling an Islamic uprising, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Dozens Die in Car Bombings
item.description: A string of car bombing killed at least 37 people on Thursday, Iraqi officials said. Three of the attacks targeted Shiite districts in the capital, Baghdad, while the fourth targeted a Kurdish neighborhood in the northern city of Kirkuk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Boy Accused of Terror Ties
item.description: A 15-year-old charged with terrorism-related offenses in Canada was initially arrested for armed robbery before the authorities realized he had planned to join jihadist fighters abroad, the police said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Democracy Advocate Gets Prison Term for Insulting King
item.description: A Bahraini court sentenced the democracy advocate Zainab al-Khawaja to three years in prison and fined her almost $8,000 on Thursday for insulting the king by tearing up his photograph, her lawyer and a human rights group said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Narendra Modi, Favoring Growth in India, Sweeps Away Environmental Rules
item.description: The new government is moving with remarkable speed to clear away regulatory burdens for industry, the armed forces, mining and power projects.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fisherman on the banks of the Daman Ganga River.

item.title: Charity in France Is Accused of Being a Front for Financing Terrorism in Syria
item.description: Pearl of Hope was shut down after the Paris Prosecutor’s office charged its two senior leaders with using charity deliveries as a front to funnel funds to jihadists.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Open Source: Chechen Leader Instagrams Battle With Militants
item.description: Ramzan Kadyrov, the Kremlin-appointed leader of Chechnya, took time out during an attack by Islamist militants to update his Instagram followers.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screen shot of an image posted on the Instagram account of Ramzan Kadyrov, the Kremlin-appointed leader of Chechnya, apparently showing the body of an Islamist militant after an attack on Thursday.

item.title: Putin’s War of Words
item.description: Ten examples of strong language used by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to inspire nationalist support at home and encourage separatists in Ukraine since the annexation of Crimea in March.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Office, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, during a news conference Monday in the new presidential palace in Ankara, Turkey.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Chip Jacobs on Struggling With Smog in Los Angeles and Beijing
item.description: Chip Jacobs, a Los Angeles-based writer who co-wrote “Smogtown: The Lung-Burning History of Pollution in Los Angeles,” discusses China’s smog crisis.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Pentagon Issues Report on Killing of a General
item.description: The report on the shooting of Maj. Gen. Harold J. Greene by an Afghan soldier praised the rapid response by other forces, but said Afghan officials did not cooperate fully in the inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Vatican Finds Stash of Money ‘Tucked Away’
item.description: The Vatican’s chief financial official said Thursday that the money had been left out of the church’s main balance sheets.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Qaeda Group in Yemen Threatens to Kill American Journalist by End of This Week
item.description: The hostage, in a video posted online, identifies himself as Luke Somers, 33, a photojournalist who was kidnapped in Sana, Yemen, in September 2013.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
